pages.text: Ales and Lagers are brewed with the same overall process. The difference is the type of yeast used during the fermentation process.$(br2)Specific types of ales and lagers require specific settings on the roaster to make the required type of roasted grain for the correct wort.

1. Grow wheat.$(br)2. Place the wheat into the stonecutter to make grain. $(br)3. Roast the grain at the correct level in the $(l:cellar/roaster)Roaster$().$(br)4. Place the roasted grain with water in the $(l:cellar/brew_kettle)Brew Kettle$(). $(br)5. Place the resulting wort into a $(l:cellar/ferment_barrel)Fermentation Barrel$() with $(6)Brewer's$() or $(6)Lager yeast$(). $(br)6. Use a glass bottle to draw out the fermented fluid. $(br)7. Enjoy the effects$(br2)The following pages list the ingredients and effects of specific ales and lagers.

pages.title: Ales
pages.text: Ales are made with $(6)Brewer's Yeast$(). The types of ale are:$(br2)$(bold)Amber Ale$() (from $(t:requires Amber Roasted Grain)$(o)Amber Wort$())$(li)Haste III (3:00)$(br2)$(bold)Brown Ale$() (from $(t:requires Brown Roasted Grain)$(o)Brown Wort$())$(li)Haste IV (6:00)$(br2)$(bold)Copper Ale$() (from $(t:requires Copper Roasted Grain)$(o)Copper Wort$())$(li)Regeneration III (3:00)
